Award.AwardTitle: GEOTRACES Pacific section: Dissolved and particulate concentrations of selected anthropogenic radionuclides along the U.S. GEOTRACES Peru-Tahiti zonal section
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International GEOTACES Program is a global study of the marine biogeochemical cycles of trace elements and their isotopes (TEIs). In 2006, the GEOTRACES Science Plan defined the mission of GEOTRACES to be "To identify processes and quantify fluxes that control the distribution of key trace elements and isotopes in the ocean and to establish the sensitivity of these distributions to changing environmental conditions". To achieve this mission, the Science Plan further sets one of the primary goals to be the determination of the global ocean concentration and speciation of TEIs as well as the biological, chemical, and physical processes governing their distribution. Anthropogenic radionuclides (i.e., those associated with nuclear energy production and defence activities) are included in the Science Plan as "parameters of interest".

In this project, a research team at the Lamont-Dougherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University will measure water column concentrations of 239Pu, 240Pu, 237Np, and 137Cs in dissolved and particulate phases along the 2013 US GEOTRACES Pacific zonal section from Peru to Tahiti. For much of the study region, these will be baseline vertical profiles of these radionuclides; that is, very few (if any) data on their distribution are currently available. These same anthropogenic radionuclides will also be measured in surface sediments at a few selected sites. Where possible, the team will compare the 2013 data to measurements made in 1972-1973, thus obtaining a four-decade perspective on processes controlling the distribution and fate of these substances.

Broader Impacts: This project will feature international collaboration with other marine radiochemists. It will also include agressive educational outreach to undergraduate and high school students to advance public understanding of environmental radioactivity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As part of a team of scientists we analyzed samples that were collected on an oceanographic research cruise that went from Peru to Tahiti in the fall of 2013. We measured anthropogenic radionuclides in seawater samples as well as solid material filtered seawater. Our work is important within the discipline Anthropogenic Marine radioactivity in terms of elucidating sources of radioactive contamination and gaining a better understanding of fundamental processes that control its transport and fate

Working with collaborators, we used a comprehensive, multi-tracer approach, in order to determine the concentrations of a suite of anthropogenic radionuclides that includes Cs-137, Pu-239, Pu-240, Np-237, U-236, and I-129 along the cruise transect. These radionuclides exhibit a range of half-lives and they have been introduced to the oceans primarily as a result of atmospheric and surface testing of nuclear weapons in the late 1950?s and early 1960?s. While the main source of these nuclides has been global stratospheric fallout, close-in fallout from equatorial Pacific test sites has also contributed (mainly in the early 1950?s) as well as other inputs from nuclear fuel reprocessing facilities (e.g., Sellafield) and accidents (e.g. Chernobyl and Fukushima). Absence in the environment at appreciable levels prior to ~1950, accurate knowledge regarding the different sources and release histories of these radionuclides, and in the case of plutonium isotopes, the ability to identify and resolve inputs from different sources make these isotopes extremely useful tools for ocean science. Numerous studies have applied these man-made tracers to study processes such as ocean currents and mixing, particle association transport and fate, sediment and pore waters dynamics as well as biological processes.  In addition to gaining a better understanding of processes that control the transport and fate of radioactive contaminants, which is listed as an anticipated benefit of the program. Where possible, can compare distributions measured in 2013 to data from the 1972-1973 GEOSECS Program, providing a ~40 year perspective on these processes. We are providing baseline profiles and sections for Pu-isotopes, Cs-137, Np-237, U-236, and I-129, which are not available or very limited in the study area.

Through method development and collaboration, we have been steadily developing a multi-tracer approach with respect to anthropogenic radionuclides in the marine environment. Given the international effort of GEOTRACES and numerous cruises, our hope is to develop the capacity to analyze numerous different radionuclides on seawater samples without overwhelming the water budgets of a particular cruise or shipping budget of a particular project. Since analytical capabilities and expertise are often divided between labs, we have participated in several cross-training activities and sampling coordination so that initial processing and separation can take place at any of our collaborators laboratories, with only the relevant processed fractions need to be shipped to the analyzing lab.

An important broader goal of our project is to develop students who can independently assess public debate and media reports and thereby aid in the creation of more scientifically literate citizens. Following a curricular model of connecting topics from science instruction to real world applications, we have created several hands on-active learning curricular components focused on developing critical thinking skills related to radioactivity in the environment. The response from the teachers we have worked with has been overwhelmingly positive, suggesting that more tools like the ones we are creating are needed.
